feed.title: [BIP Proposal] Limit ScriptPubkey Size >= 520 Bytes Consensus.

entry.title: [BIP Proposal] Limit ScriptPubkey Size >= 520 Bytes Consensus.
entry.summary:
The discussion emphasizes the capability of public key (pubkey) scripts to handle large data requirements by leveraging a witness, underpinned by a cryptographically secure hash function. This approach negates concerns about the size limitations, with a specific mention that the necessity for 4096 bits is unlikely. The resilience of SHA512 as a hash function is highlighted, especially in the context of potential threats from quantum algorithms. It is suggested that quantum computing may reduce the effective strength of hash functions by half, yet SHA512 is considered robust enough to withstand such reductions under even the most challenging scenarios.
Moreover, the conversation touches on the complexity of finding collisions within hash functions, indicating that simply discovering any collision is insufficient for concerns like script or Merkle root integrity. There's a stance against integrating unlocking conditions directly into the Unspent Transaction Output (UTXO) set, suggesting it might not contribute positively to the system's health.
The email concludes without taking a firm stance on whether restrictions on these technologies should be temporary or permanent, implying a level of uncertainty or openness to future developments in this area. The inclusion of technical details and considerations reflects a deep dive into the specifics of cryptographic security and its implications for Bitcoin development, without advocating for immediate concern over theoretical limitations or vulnerabilities introduced by quantum computing advancements.
